awd_titl_txt: Understanding Molecular-Recognition Properties of Helical Pores under Non-equilibrium Conditions
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Bing Gong of the State University of New York at Buffalo and Professor Xiao Cheng Zeng of the University of Nebraska-Lincoln collaborate to develop novel approaches to sensing differences among sugar molecules.  In this project, the team designs and synthesizes long-chain molecules that coil up like springs.  The interior space of these "molecular springs" interact with different kinds of sugar molecules with different strengths.  By embedding these "molecular springs" in a cell wall and monitoring the passage of sugar molecules through the interior spaces, the research team aims to develop a method to recognize and sense sugars in water.  The results of this research may have implications in separations and medical diagnostics.  The broader impacts involve training graduate and undergraduate students, incorporating research into teaching, conducting workshops, reaching out to underrepresented groups, and broadly disseminating this work to the scientific community. 

With the support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, this project aims to probe and understand molecular recognition of sugar and sugar alcohols in aqueous media under non-equilibrium conditions.  The research team prepares aromatic oligoamide foldamers that form helical coils.  When embedded in membranes, the oxygen-rich, electrostatically negative inner pores of these coils provide thruways for ions to pass through the membrane.  In addition, the presence of numerous amide oxygen atoms in the inner pores of the membrane-bound foldamers serve as hydrogen-bond acceptors that enable multiple hydrogen-bonding interactions with sugars and sugar alcohols in different strengths.  Such interactions, being dynamic and transient, especially in water, result in the perturbation of ion currents through the transmembrane pores.  Depending on their structures and properties, different types of carbohydrates perturb the flow of ions through the pores differently, which can be detected very sensitively.  By measuring the changes in transmembrane ion conductance in the presence of different saccharides and their derivatives, the research aims to monitor and understand molecular recognition of these molecules under non-equilibrium conditions.  Specifically, this work focuses on synthesizing oligoamides of different lengths (8mer, 16mer, 32mer, and 64mer) and examining the effects of various sugars and sugar alcohols on the transmembrane ion currents through the pore-forming foldamers. Vesicle-based assays are performed to provide a rapid but qualitative screening of the effects of chosen carbohydrates, followed by measurement of single-channel currents to reveal the signatures of different carbohydrate molecules.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project, supported by the NSF (CHE-1905094), aimed at synthesizing aromatic oligoamide foldamers that fold into pore-containing helices, forming membrane-spanning channels based on self-assembled short helices or single helices with lengths matching the thickness of the lipid bilayers, developing reliable assays for transmembrane cation transport, and the detection and differentiation of different sugar molecules based on disturbed transmembrane ionic currents.

The completion of the proposed research aims has: (1) established the synthesis of aromatic oligoamides that fold into multi-helices with the longest one having 24 residues corresponding to a helix of ~3.7 turns and a length of ~13 Å. The head-to-tail assembly of three molecules of such a helix will to a membrane-spanning channel; (2) determined the crystal structure of a 16-residue oligoamide, which has provided the structural details of the first multi-turn helix in this series of foldamers; (3) observed well-defined transmembrane ion transport in the presence of our pore-containing helices with vesicle-based assays; (4) observed disturbed, i.e., different transmembrane cation transport in the presence of different sugars (e.g., glucose vs fructose) and sugar alcohols (e.g., sorbitol vs mannitol); (5) detected well-defined single-channel conductance mediated by our pore-containing helices.

Results from this research have revealed the synthetic conditions for preparing long oligoamides that fold into multi-turn helices, based on which further optimization is being performed to achieve the synthesis of oligomers that fold into longer helices of more turns, with the objective of obtaining helices with lengths that span the thickness of the lipid bilayer and thus serve as unimolecular transmembrane channels. The solved crystal structure of a 16-residue oligoamide has provided answers to fundamental questions on the structural parameters that are essential for the accurate prediction of the folded structures of longer helices, based on which the types of helices needed for fabricating membrane-spanning channels can be designed.

Outcome from this research has also provided initial evidence suggesting the extraordinary ion-transporting capability of our pore-containing helices, which exhibit readily detectable ionic currents that are essential for establishing these foldamer-based channels as a new class of sensors based on these sub-nanometer pores. Uncovering the remaining details and mechanism behind such the ion transport, especially disturbed ion transport in the presence of various sugars, could allow the eventually differentiation of otherwise very similar sugar molecules.

During the funding period of this award, the PI’s group has published 13 papers with 5 publications acknowledging this award. Our paper are in leading journals such as Journal of the American Chemical Society, Chemical Communications, and Organic Letters, that attracted wide attention. This project has provided the opportunity for training students and postdocs. Four undergraduate students, seven graduate students, and one postdoc had participated in this research.
